abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impacts substantial. Lessons point at the
            importance of stakeholder participation in project design,
            since it is key to promoting ownership of project
            activities, and gaining support for project interventions,
            while helping adjust the design, and in addition, provides a
            source of quality control on project outputs. This was
            especially true in the teachers participation early on, who
            contributed to the success of educational reforms.
            Similarly, consultations with beneficiaries regarding the
            content of training is key to success; however, it was
            widely felt, both by trained teachers, and staff of the
            Ministry of Education, that they were not sufficiently
            consulted on the selection of their training, perceived
            sometimes as redundant, or, not at all suitable to their
            needs. Hence, while the provision of training is not
            sufficient to guarantee behavioral changes, it does need to
            run parallel with technical assistance provision, and
            hands-on classroom work, to allow adequate transmittal of
            acquired skills. Regrettably, the absence of a local
            capacity assessment may hinder procurement, and financial
            reporting guidelines, whereas realistic capacity assessment
            would conduce to the needed start-up support for an
            effective implementation. Moreover, the cost of civil works
            should be based on site-specific construction designs, or
            alternatively, on price contingencies built into cost
            estimates to minimize cost underestimates.

18231319.trustfund:
TF032383-LAC REGION - EDUCATION;HEATLH,TF034299-COLOMBIA - OECS BASIC EDUCATION
            REFORM PROJECTS,TF033602-LAC REGION - HEALTH AND EDUCATION
18231319.majtheme: Public sector governance,Human development,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Basic Education Reform Project has
            the overall objective of accelerating human resource
            development to ensure that the requisite manpower exists to
            attain the desired economic transition in Dominica. The
            project is intended to: 1) strengthen the planning and
            institutional capacity of the Ministry of Education, Youth
            Affairs and Sports (MOE) to guide and carry out the
            long-term development of the sector, while enabling it to
            initiate significant, urgent measures to address system-wide
            qualitative problems and expansion needs at the secondary
            level; and 2) serve as a catalyst for a major adjustment
            process, focused on revision to more reasonable levels of
            primary and secondary teacher to student ratios, in line
            with ratios of countries of comparable economic and social
            development. The project comprises three major components:
            1) a strengthening management and planning component; 2) a
            qualitative improvement of basic education component, which
            will enhance the quality of teaching and learning; and 3) an
            expansion and conservation of school places component, which
            will assist MOE to provide more secondary school places in
            the most under-served districts to reduce long distance
            travel and facilitate access to educational opportunities.
